Comment: Frankly, people should pay so much more attention at the state and local level first. Setting aside that there are consequential things happening now at the federal level, most of them are being driven by the executive branch and even for the legislative stuff there is little to be done to slow down these shifts. It's also easy to get lost in the weeds on issues that have no hope of moving.  State and local politics though? Tend to be more straightforward, have real and understandable impacts for your community and state, have so few people interacting on the issues that you can legitimately make your voice heard, and are closer to you and more accessible. If you hear about a bill that concerns you, you can actually organize a group of people to testify on the bill and often testify in front of the committee yourself. Try doing that in front of Congress.

Comment: Education, but more specifically, *adept media intuition and literacy,* by far. I'm of the view that the poor media literacy is the single greatest threat to healthy social and political discourse. There is a stunning lack of curiosity in the pursuit of truth and understanding. Most people cannot think in abstracts while being unwilling to listen to experts. They struggle in dissonance arousing situations. There's a Dunning-Kruger epidemic in the online era of media consumption. Furthermore, this problem transcends politics. Many people cannot absorb and digest the complexities and nuance of a fictional narrative to save their lives. They have to be explicitly told what to think and feel, like children, and they very often *miss the point* entirely.
